isis.stitle: T 444E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1997) - SECTION 2.3: PERFORMANCE DIAGNOSTICS - T 444E ENGINE - INTAKE RESTRICTION

svcprocinfo.para:
Refer to Table 2.23
for the Intake Restriction Test of the diagnostic form.

entry.para: • Check filter minder if equipped. (If yellow band is latched @ 25" H2O, replace filter)
• Measure at High idle & no load

svcsubproc.title: Purpose
svcsubproc.para: To determine if an intake/air cleaner restriction exists. Often a low power and poor fuel economy complaint is simply due to a dirty air cleaner element. In this test, the gauge is inserted in the air cleaner housing. As the air cleaner element accumulates dirt, restriction to air flow increases. If restriction exceeds specifications, replace the air cleaner element or elements.

note.para: A high intake restriction may cause a considerable amount of black or blue smoke when starting the engine.

step1.para: Refer to appropriate "Operation and Maintenance Manual" "Air Cleaner Restriction Gauge and Indicator", for detailed information.

note.para: The air cleaner is to be replaced when the restriction reaches the maximum allowable limit. The restriction can be measured by a service indicator, water manometer or magnehelic gauge.

step1.para: Inspect the element(s) for damaged gaskets or dents. If they exhibit either they should be replaced.

svcsubproc.title: Single Element Air Cleaner
svcsubproc.para: Measure air cleaner restriction as follows:

step1.para:
Attach the restriction test gauge ( Figure 2.46
) at air cleaner housing tap location.
Run engine at high idle RPM.
Replace the air cleaner element when the test gauge shows a restriction greater than 12.5 in. H2O (3.13 kPa).

note.para: 1: The true maximum air cleaner restriction can only be obtained when operating the engine at full load and rated speed. The vehicle mounted indicator or vacuum gauge will sense maximum restriction. When 25 in. H2O (6.22 kPa) is sensed on the vehicle mounted gauges, replace the air cleaner element. For convenience, air cleaner restriction can be measured at high idle (no load); however, the element must be replaced when 12.5 in. H2o (3.13 Kpa) is measured.
2: High air cleaner restriction can cause turbocharger seals to unseat, causing oil to be drawn through seals and into the engine.

svcsubproc.title: Dual Element Cleaner
svcsubproc.para: The dual element air cleaner provides a large primary (outer) filter element and an optional small secondary (inner) filter element. The secondary element should be used in dusty environments.

The dual element air cleaner assembly air cleaner restriction connection ( Figures 2.47 and 2.48
) is located between the primary and the secondary element in the bottom of the air cleaner housing. This arrangement allows only the primary (outer) element to be sensed by the restriction indicator or dash mounted vacuum gauge. THE INNER ELEMENT IS NOT RECORDED ON THE RESTRICTION INDICATOR OR DASH MOUNTED VACUUM GAUGE.
To determine inner element restriction use the:

svcsubproc.title: Visual Check Procedure
svcsubproc.para: Visually inspect the restriction indicator built into the inner element or inner element retaining nut.

note.para: Two different indicators are the result of two different suppliers. Replace the element when the green dot disappears from the element or from the window in the retaining nut.

important.para: EACH SUPPLIER'S RETAINING NUT REQUIRES A DIFFERENT TORQUE. REFER TO FIGURES 2.47 AND 2.48 .

figure.caption: Figure 2.47 - Dual Element Air Cleaner With Indicator in End Cap
Figure 2.48 - Dual Element Air Cleaner Retaining Nut Indicator

item.para: Snow, plastic bags or other foreign material may restrict air flow at the air cleaner inlet. On engines recently repaired, rags or cap plugs may have been inadvertently left in the intake system.

svcsubproc.title: Tools Required
svcsubproc.para: Model D-200 Pressure Test Kit (ZTSE-2239), magnehelic gauge or water manometer.
